tests.title: Linear Algebra: Test 1
tests.topics: Systems of linear equations, matirx operations, inverse matrix, eigenvalues, eigenvectors

questions.question: \begin{aligned} x + y +3z & = 0\\ x + 2y -2z & = 3\\ 3x +9y +k & = 19\end{aligned}
questions.prompt: Find the value of $\small \boldsymbol{k}$ for which the following system has $\small \textbf{no solution}$.

questions.question: A =\begin{bmatrix}0 & 0 & 1 & 0\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\ -37 & 24 & -10 & 0 \\ 24 & -37 & 0 & -10 \end{bmatrix} \text{,  } \vec{x} = \begin{bmatrix}-8i\\8i\\48+40i\\-48-40i\end{bmatrix}
questions.prompt: Find the $\small \textbf{eigenvalue}$ associated with the $\small \textbf{following eigenvector}$.
questions.extra: if your answer is a + bi, then enter a,b in the answer box (no spaces)

questions.question: A =\begin{bmatrix}4 & -3 & 4\\ 0 &-4 & 0\\-1 & 7 & -1 \end{bmatrix}
questions.prompt: Find the $\small \textbf{eigenvalues } \lambda$ of the following matrix.
questions.extra: separate your answers with a comma (least to greatest; no spaces)

questions.question: \begin{aligned} x_{1} -3x_{2} -6x_{3} + 8x_{4} & = 2\\ 4x_{1} -5x_{2} -7x_{3} + 5x_{4} & = 5\\ -8x_{1} +3x_{2} -3x_{3} + 17x_{4} & = -23\end{aligned}
questions.prompt: Determine whether the following $\small \textbf{linear system}$ has $\small \textbf{one solution, no solutions, or infinitely}$ many solutions.

questions.question: A =\begin{bmatrix}1 & 1 & 5 & 9\\ -9 & 2 & -5 & 8\\9 & 7 & -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \text{,  } B = \begin{bmatrix}5 \\-6\\-1\\3 \end{bmatrix}
questions.prompt: Compute the $\small \textbf{product}$ AB. $\textbf{Find }\boldsymbol{AB_{31}}$

questions.question: A = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 1 & -2\\-10 & -1 & 4 \\ -2 & -1 & 2 \end{bmatrix}
questions.prompt: Consider the following matrix $\small A$, and let $\small \boldsymbol {B= A^{−1}}$. $\small\text{Compute}$ $\small \boldsymbol{b_{31}+b_{32}+b_{33}}$.

questions.question: C=\begin{bmatrix} a + 3g & -g & 3d \\ b +3h & -h & 3e \\ c+3i & -i & 3f \end{bmatrix}
questions.prompt:
Suppose that $\small \boldsymbol{\det(A) = -3}$. Let $\small B$ be another 3 × 3 matrix (not given here) with $\small \boldsymbol{\det(B) = 4}$. 
Find $\small \boldsymbol{\det(C)}$

questions.question: A = \begin{bmatrix} 8 & 8 & -1 \\ *& *& * \\ * & * & * \end{bmatrix}\text{,  }\vec{x} = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \\ -4\end{bmatrix}
questions.prompt: Given that $\small \boldsymbol {\vec{x}}$ is an $\small \textbf{eigenvector}$ of the matrix $\small A$, what is the corresponding $\small \textbf{eigenvalue } \lambda$?

Let $\small A$ be a 4 × 13 matrix, and let $\small B$ be m × n. Suppose that $\small B^{T}A^{T}$ is a 24 x 4 matrix.
What is the value of $\small \boldsymbol{m}$?

questions.question: A = \begin{bmatrix} \sqrt{2} & 2 & 1 \\ 6 & 1 & 4 \\ 1 & 8 & 3 \end{bmatrix}
questions.prompt: Let $\small \boldsymbol{B = adj(A)}$. $\small \textbf{Find }  \boldsymbol{b_{33}}$?

tests.title: Calculus I: Test 2
tests.topics: Implicit/explicit integration, differential applications in optimization, critical points, intervals of concavity/increase/decrease, L'Hospital's Rule, Mean Value Theorem, and hyperbolic functions

questions.question: f(x) = \ln(\ln{x^{x^{2}}})
questions.prompt: What is the $\small \textbf{instantaneous rate of change}$ of $\small \boldsymbol{f(x)}$ at $\small \boldsymbol{x = e}$

questions.question: \int_{0}^{1} \sqrt{x+10} \,dx
questions.prompt: Which of the following $\small \textbf{limits}$ would correctly correspond the following $\small \textbf{integral}$.

questions.question: \int_{0}^{\frac{1}{2}} \cosh{2x}\,dx
questions.prompt: Use $\small \textbf{U-Substitution}$ to evaluate the following $\small \textbf{definite integral}$

questions.question: \lim_{x\rightarrow \infty} (\frac{e^{x}}{\ln{x}})
questions.prompt: $\small \textbf{Evaluate}$ the following $\small \textbf{limit}$

questions.question: f(x) = \ln{3x} + \tan{2^{x}}
questions.prompt: Determine $\small \boldsymbol{f'(x)}$

questions.question: f(x) = \begin{cases} x^{3} + 2x^{2} -5 & 0 \leq x < 5 \\ \frac{1}{x^{2}} & 5 \leq x \end{cases}
questions.prompt: At what point $(x,y)$ does the following $\small \textbf{piecewise function}$ have an $\small \textbf{absolute minimum}$?

questions.question: f(x) = \sinh({\cosh{(\ln{(\ln{x})})}})
questions.prompt: $\small \textbf{Evalute}$ the following function at $\small \boldsymbol{x = e^{2}}$.
Which of the following is $\small \textbf{false}$ regarding the satisfaction of the $\small \textbf{Mean Value Theorem}$?
questions.solution: \footnotesize\text{If f(a) = f(b) then there always lies a point on (a,b) such that f'(c) = 1}
questions.C: \footnotesize \text{There is a point c on (a,b) such that f(b) - f(a) = f'(c)(b-a)}
questions.D: \footnotesize\text{If f(a) = f(b) then there always lies a point on (a,b) such that f'(c) = 1}
questions.E: \footnotesize \text{There is a point c on (a,b) such that }\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{f'(c)} = (-a+b)

questions.question: f(x)=\frac{x-4}{x^{2}-16x}
questions.prompt: Find the $\small \textbf{intervals of increase}$ on $\small \boldsymbol{f(x)}$

A farmer with $\small \textbf{750 ft}$ of fencing wants to enclose a $\small \textbf{rectangular area}$ and then divide it into $\small \textbf{four pens}$ with fencing parallel to one side of the rectangle. Write an $\small \textbf{expression}$ for the $\small \textbf{total area}$ of the fence in terms of $\small \boldsymbol{x}$.

questions.question: f(x) = \frac{1}{\ln{x}}
questions.prompt: Find the intervals of $\small \textbf{downwards concanvity}$ of $\small \boldsymbol{f(x)}$.

questions.question: \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{1}{\sqrt{x^{2}+4}}dx
questions.prompt: Evaluate the following definite integral
questions.extra: Submit 'diverges' if the integral is divergent

questions.question: \int_{1}^{\infty} \frac{\sin^2{x}+\cos^2{x}}{x^{10}}dx
questions.prompt: Evaluate the following definite integral
questions.extra: Submit 'diverges' if the integral is divergent

questions.question: \int sec^4(x)tan^5(x)dx
questions.prompt: Evaluate the following indefinite integral
questions.extra: Enter your answer symbolically (Do not include +C)

questions.question: \int_{0}^{1} \frac{\sec^2{x}}{x\sqrt{x}} dx
questions.prompt: Use the Comparison Theorem to determine whether the integral is convergent or divergent

questions.question: \int_{1}^{\infty} (\frac{1}{3})^{x} dx
questions.prompt: Evaluate the following definite integral

questions.question: a_n = \frac{2n^{2}}{n^{2}-16}
questions.prompt: Find the limit of the following sequence

questions.question: \sum_{i=1}^{70} \frac{2^{i-2}}{3^{i-1}}
questions.prompt: Evaluate the following sum

questions.question: a_{n+1} = f(a_{n}) \text{ and } \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} a_{n} = L
questions.prompt: A recursive relation converges at a fixed point when:
A series which is increasing, negative, and continous for the entire domain defintely diverges

questions.question: a_{n} = 1 + \sqrt{\frac{1}{1+a_{n-1}}}
questions.prompt: Assuming the limit exits, find the limit of the following recursive sequence:

questions.question: \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \sec({\frac{\sqrt{n+2}-3}{n-7}})-1
questions.prompt: Use the divergence test on the following series
questions.extra: Enter 'false' if it fails the divergence test, and 'true' if it passes it

questions.question: \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^{2}-4}
questions.prompt: If applicable, use the integral test on the following series
questions.extra: Enter 'false' if it fails the integral test, and 'true' if it passes it

questions.question: \int_{0}^{2} \frac{x^{2}-4}{\sqrt{x}}
questions.prompt: Evaluate the following definite integral
Determine the $\small \textbf{magnitude}$ of the vector represented by the coordinates $(4,7)$ and $(-2,5)$.

questions.question: \small \vec{u} = \begin{bmatrix}2\\-3\\5\end{bmatrix},\,\vec{v}= \begin{bmatrix}-4\\1\\-2\end{bmatrix}
questions.prompt: Calculate the $\small\textbf{dot product}$ of the following vectors

questions.question: \small \vec{u} = \begin{bmatrix}1\\3\\2\end{bmatrix},\, \vec{v} = \begin{bmatrix}2\\-1\\4\end{bmatrix}
questions.prompt: Find the $\small \textbf{angle in degrees}$ between the following vectors:
questions.extra: Round to the nearest tenth (one decimal place). Do NOT include the degrees symbol

questions.question: \small \vec{v} = \begin{bmatrix}2\\-1\\4\end{bmatrix}
questions.prompt: Find a $\small \textbf{unit vector}$ in the direction of $\small \boldsymbol{\vec{v}}$.

questions.question: \small \vec{a} = \begin{bmatrix}1\\2\\3\end{bmatrix},\,\vec{b} = \begin{bmatrix}3\\2\\1\end{bmatrix},\,\vec{c} = \begin{bmatrix}4\\5\\6\end{bmatrix}
questions.prompt: Are the following vectors $\small \textbf{coplanar}$?

Two forces act on an object, one with a magnitude of $\footnotesize \textbf{20 newtons directly east}$, and another with a magnitude of $\footnotesize \textbf{15 newtons directly north}$. What is the $\footnotesize \textbf{magnitude}$ and $\footnotesize \textbf{direction}$ of the resultant force acting on the object? Round the angle to one decimal place (relative to the positive x-axis) and round the magnitude to the nearest newton.
questions.extra: Enter your answer as 'magnitude,angle' (e.g. 15,63.3) no spaces

tests.title: Discrete Math: Test 1
tests.topics: Propositions, propositoinal logic, propositional functions, logical equivalance, quantified statements, set theory, rules of inference

questions.prompt: Which of the following is defintely a $\small \textbf{proposition}$?

questions.question: f(x) = \sqrt{16-x^{2}}
questions.prompt: What $\small \textbf{set}$ would represent the domain for which $\small \boldsymbol{f(x)}$ is $\small \textbf{defined}$?
Which of the following $\small \textbf{compound propositions}$ are $\small \textbf{logically equivalent}$?

Suppose we have two $\small \textbf{sets}$ $\small A$ and $\small B$, where $\small \,\boldsymbol{A = \{1,2,3\}}$ and $\small \,\boldsymbol{B = \{2,4,6\}}$. 
Which of the following $\small \textbf{quantified statements}$ is $\small \textbf{true}$?

questions.question: \forall{x} \exists{y} P(x,y)
questions.prompt:
Let $\small \boldsymbol{P}$ represent the $\small \textbf{predicate 'x passed y'}$, where the domain of $\small \boldsymbol{x}$ is the students in a high school and the domain of $\small \boldsymbol{y}$ are the courses offered in the school. 
Find the $\small \textbf{negation}$ of the following $\small \textbf{quantified expression}$
questions.solution: \exists{x}\forall{y}\neg{P(x,y)} \tiny \text{, There exists a student that did not pass any courses offered.}
questions.A: \exists{x}\forall{y}\neg{P(x,y)} \tiny \text{, There exists a student that did not pass any courses offered.}
questions.B: \forall{x} \exists{y} \neg{P(x,y)} \tiny \text{, Every student did not pass a course offered.}
questions.C: \forall{y} \exists{x} P(x,y) \tiny \text{, Every course has a student that passed it.}
questions.D: \forall{x} \exists{y} \neg{P(y,x)} \tiny \text{, There exists a student that did not pass any courses offered.}
questions.E: \exists{x}\forall{y}\neg{P(x,y)} \tiny \text{, There exists a student that did not pass all courses offered.}

questions.prompt: Suppose that the following statement is true: 'If John studies for his exam, he will pass it.' Which of the following statements can be $\small \textbf{concluded}$ from this using $\small \textbf{modus tollens}$?
questions.solution: \small \text{John failed his exam, therefore he did not study.}
questions.A: \small \text{John passed his exam, therefore he studied.}
questions.B: \small \text{John failed his exam, therefore he did not study.}
questions.C: \small \text{John did not study for his exam, therefore he did not pass it}
questions.D: \small \text{John passed his exam, therefore the statement is false}
questions.E: \small \text{Johs failed his exam, therefore he slept during the test}

questions.prompt: Suppose that the following statement is true: 'If it is raining, then the ground is wet.' Which of the following statements can be concluded using $\small \textbf{modus ponens}$ if we know that it is $\small \textbf{raining outside}$  ?
questions.C: \small \text{We cannot conclude anything about the ground being wet or not}$

questions.prompt:
Suppose that the following two statements are true: 

1) If it is sunny, then Sarah will go to the beach. 
2) If Sarah goes to the beach, then she will bring her sunscreen. 

Which of the following statements can be logically inferred using $\small \textbf{hypothetical syllogism}$?
questions.solution: \small \text{If it is sunny, then Sarah will bring her sunscreen.}
questions.A: \small \text{If it is sunny, then Sarah will bring her sunscreen.}
questions.B: \small \text{If Sarah brings her sunscreen, then it is sunny.}
questions.C: \small \text{If it not sunny, then Sarah will not bring her sunscreen.}
questions.D: \small \text{If Sarah does not bring her suncreen, then it is not sunny}

tests.title: Calculus II: Test 2
tests.topics: Function representation of power series, Taylor/Maclaurin series

questions.question: f(x)=\sqrt[4]{1-x}
questions.prompt: Use the binomial series to expand the function as a power series. Also, find the radius of convergence.

questions.question: f(x)=\ln{e^{x\pi}}
questions.prompt: Evaluate the Taylor Series of $f(x)$ centered at $a = \pi$ and let $x = -\pi$

questions.question: f(x)=\log{(10^{10x^{2}})}
questions.prompt: Evaluate the Taylor Series of $f(x)$ centered at $a = 10$ and let $x = -10$

questions.question: \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{n}\pi^{2n}}{\pi^{n}(2n)!}
questions.prompt: Evaluate the following series

questions.question: 1-\ln{2}+\frac{(\ln{2})^2}{2!}-\frac{(\ln{2})^3}{3!}+\dots
questions.prompt: Evaluate the following series
$\text{Say }\boldsymbol{f(x) =\sqrt{x}}$, approximated by $T_{3}(x)$ about $x = 3$ on the interval $[2,4]$. Estimate the upper bound on the error in this approximation.

$\text{Say }\boldsymbol{f(x) =\ln({\tan{x}+\sec{x}})}$, approximated by $T_{0}(x)$ about $x = -\pi$ on the interval $[\frac{2\pi}{3},\pi]$. Estimate the upper bound on the error in this approximation.

The half-life of the plutonium isotope is 24,360 years. If 1kg of plutonium is released into the atmosphere by a nuclear accident, find the amount of years it will take for 75% of the isotope to decay. Also, given $k$ is constant, what can you conclude about the relationship between the initial amount of plutonium ($y_{0} > 0$) and the time needed for the sample to decay by some arbitrary percentage ($0<c\leq100$)?
questions.solution: \scriptsize{48720 \text{ years; The time required to decay to some } (y_{0} \cdot c) \text{ is a constant for all }y_{0}}
questions.A: \scriptsize{48720 \text{ years; The time required to decay to some } (y_{0} \cdot c) \text{ is a constant for all }y_{0}}
questions.B: \scriptsize{48720 \text{ years; The time required to decay to some } (y_{0} \cdot c) \text{ is dependent on }y_{0}}
questions.C: \scriptsize{10110 \text{ years; The time required to decay to some } (y_{0} \cdot c) \text{ is a constant for all }y_{0}}
questions.D: \scriptsize{10110 \text{ years; The time required to decay to some } (y_{0} \cdot c) \text{ is dependent on }y_{0}}
questions.E: \scriptsize{48720 \text{ years; No conclusions can be made}}
